description: Late Middle English, alteration of whitflaw, the first element coming from either Middle Dutch vijt or Low German fit (“abscess”), borrowed from Latin fīcus (“fig-shaped (ulcer)”), though also influenced by white.  The Latin loan also existed in other languages, such as Old English fic (“hemorrhoids”). See flaw.

entries.meaning: An infection under the cuticle of a fingernail or toenail.
